computer.coprocessor: Socket for an optional 68882 math coprocessor
computer.description:
The Macintosh Color Classic (aka Performa 250) had same footprint as the original Macintosh. It was the first mac using a 10" (9" viewable) colour monitor (Sony CRT) and the last of the original all-in-one Macintosh line to be sold in the US market.
Its main board had the same design as the Mac LC II, featuring a 16 MHz 68030 CPU. Sadly, its address bus was limited to 16 bit and allowed only 10 MB of maximum RAM.
The Color Classic could emulate the Apple II thank to an expansion card inserted into its PDS slot.
An improved version, called Color Classic II (aka Performa 275) was launched in late 1993 in Canada then in Japan. It had the same motherboard as the LC/Performa 550 with a 33 MHz CPU, a 32-bit bus and up to 36 MB of available RAM.
Some people call the LC/Performa 550 the "Fat Color Classic II" because of the wider monitor.
____________
Jeremy Dilatush adds: This machine's color graphics were *slow* so I usually ran mine in black and white mode. Yes, it made a major difference.
Gwion Mainwaring reports: There are PPC Upgrades available and this will make your Color Classic a lot faster so you could run Mac OS 8 or 9. OS9 would be a bit slow. But i think you can only run OS 9 on a Color Classic II.

emulator.description: Demonstration version of a commercial software (MS DOS & Win95)
emulator.name: Executor

emulator.description: A commercial Software which emulates the Atari ST/TT and the Mac 128/Plus/2 (Win95 / Win NT)
emulator.name: Gemulator

emulator.description: Same as Apple lisa emulator for unix but ported to windows
emulator.name: LisaEm

emulator.description: PearPC is an architecture-independent PowerPC platform emulator capable of running most PowerPC operating systems.
emulator.name: PearPC

emulator.description: Demo version of a commercial software (Linux / NextStep)
emulator.name: Executor
vMac - The Virtual Macintosh Emulator Project

emulator.description: Basilisk II is an Open Source 68k Macintosh emulator. Good emulator, runs on several platforms, even Amiga
emulator.name: Basilisk II

emulator.description: Mini vMac, a spin off of the program vMac, emulates a Macintosh Plus and Macintosh SE. So far it works on Macintosh OS, Microsoft Windows, and the X Window System.
emulator.name: Mini vMac

computer.graphics: 512 x 384 dots. Could be expanded to 640 x 480 with significant hardware modifications.
computer.keyboard: Typewriter type 82 key with numeric keypad and arrow keys
computer.name: Macintosh Color Classic
computer.ports: 2 x ADB, 2 x serial, SCSI, sound In/Out
computer.power: Built in switching power supply unit
computer.ram: 4 MB up to 10 MB (although 12 MB could sit in the slots)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;FRONT VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Volume and brightness adjustments are located on the front panel.<
<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;RUNNING SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Color Classic is running Maelstrom game.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Two ADB ports - Mini-Din sockets<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Two Serial ports - Printer and modem<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> SCSI DB25 connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Sound input jack<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Sound output jack<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> The rear panel can be easily opened to slide out the motherboard<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> CRT horizontal and vertical centering<br><

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Analog board holding the power supply unit and the video circuitry<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Intermediate bay which supports the floppy drive, the hard disk drive and the speaker<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Motherboard<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Sound chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> SCSI chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> PDS expansion slot<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Socket for the optional 68882 math coprocessor<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Motorola 68030 CPU<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Custom Apple chipset in charge of memory management and various I/O<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> 1 MB ROM chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Video chip and its associated 256 KB RAM<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> 4 MB on-board RAM chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</font></b> SIMM socket for the video RAM expansion<br> <b><font color="blue">(11)</font></b> SIMM sockets for the main RAM expansion<

computer.sound: Mono 16-bit - Built-in speaker - sound output jack
computer.text: No text mode. Bit mapped characters
computer.vram: 256 KB up to 512 KB (specific SIMM secket)
